para.sentence:
Elementary nonrational solutions of \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize III}} are w(z;\mu,0,0,-\mu\kappa^{3})=\kappa z^{1/3}, w(z;0,-2\kappa,0,4\kappa\mu-\lambda^{2})=z(\kappa(\ln z)^{2}+\lambda\ln z+\mu), w(z;-
u^{2}\lambda,0,
u^{2}(\lambda^{2}-4\kappa\mu),0)=\dfrac{z^{
u-1}}{ \kappa z^{2
u}+\lambda z^{
u}+\mu}, with \kappa , \lambda , \mu , and 
u arbitrary constants.
In the case \gamma=0 and \alpha\delta\neq 0 we assume, as in §32.2(ii),
Then \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize III}} has algebraic solutions iff \beta=2n, with n\in\mathbb{Z}.

These are rational solutions in \zeta=z^{1/3} of the form w(z)=\ifrac{P_{n^{2}+1}(\zeta)}{Q_{n^{2}}(\zeta)}, where P_{n^{2}+1}(\zeta) and Q_{n^{2}}(\zeta) are polynomials of degrees n^{2}+1 and n^{2} , respectively, with no common zeros.
For examples and plots see Clarkson (2003a) and Milne et al. (1997).

\mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize III}} with \beta=\delta=0 has a first integral z^{2}(w^{\prime})^{2}+2zww^{\prime}=(C+2\alpha zw+\gamma z^{2}w^{2})w^{2}, with C an arbitrary constant, which is solvable by quadrature.
\mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize III}} with \alpha=\beta=\gamma=\delta=0 , has the general solution w(z)=Cz^{\mu} , with C and \mu arbitrary constants.

Elementary nonrational solutions of \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize V}} are w(z;\mu,-\tfrac{1}{8},-\mu\kappa^{2},0)=1+\kappa z^{1/2}, w(z;0,0,\mu,-\tfrac{1}{2}\mu^{2})=\kappa\exp\left(\mu z\right), with \kappa and \mu arbitrary constants.

\mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize V}} , with \delta=0 , has algebraic solutions if either \mspace{17.0mu }(\alpha,\beta,\gamma)=(\tfrac{1}{2}\mu^{2},-\tfrac{1}{8}(2n-1) ^{2},-1), or \mspace{5.0mu }(\alpha,\beta,\gamma)=(\tfrac{1}{8}(2n-1)^{2},-\tfrac{1}{2}\mu^ {2},1), with n\in\mathbb{Z} and \mu arbitrary.

These are rational solutions in \zeta=z^{1/2} of the form w(z)=\ifrac{P_{n^{2}-n+1}(\zeta)}{Q_{n^{2}-n}(\zeta)}, where P_{n^{2}-n+1}(\zeta) and Q_{n^{2}-n}(\zeta) are polynomials of degrees n^{2}-n+1 and n^{2}-n , respectively, with no common zeros.
\mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize V}} , with \gamma=\delta=0 , has a first integral z^{2}(w^{\prime})^{2}=(w-1)^{2}(2\alpha w^{2}+Cw-2\beta), with C an arbitrary constant, which is solvable by quadrature.
For examples and plots see Clarkson (2005).
\mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize V}} , with \alpha=\beta=0 and \gamma^{2}+2\delta=0 , has solutions w(z)=C\exp\left(\pm\sqrt{-2\delta}z\right) , with C an arbitrary constant.

An elementary algebraic solution of \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize VI}} is w(z;\tfrac{1}{2}\kappa^{2},-\tfrac{1}{2}\kappa^{2},\tfrac{1}{2}\mu^{2},\tfrac{ 1}{2}(1-\mu^{2}))=z^{1/2}, with \kappa and \mu arbitrary constants.
Dubrovin and Mazzocco (2000) classifies all algebraic solutions for the special case of \mbox{P}_{\mbox{\scriptsize VI}} with \beta=\gamma=0 , \delta=\tfrac{1}{2}.
For further examples of algebraic solutions see Andreev and Kitaev (2002),Boalch (2005, 2006),Gromak et al. (2002, §48),Hitchin (2003),Masuda (2003), andMazzocco (2001b).
